references: In this section, we present several different methods for uncertainty modeling, with specific formulations shown in Table 7. Each method provides unique insights into quantifying uncertainty, which is crucial for improving model robustness and decision-making in complex scenarios.

In this section, we provide a detailed description of the process for calculating the AUROC, as illustrated in Fig 6. Similar to previous work(Huang et al., 2024), the experiments are conducted on the TriviaQA dataset, using the Llama-2-7b-chat-hf model. First, we construct prompts suitable for TriviaQA in the format shown in Table 5 and input them into the LLM. At this stage, we obtain an output y from the model, as well as the logits corresponding to both the prompt and the output. For the output
y^^\hat{y}over^ start_ARG italic_y end_ARG, we compute its score using a correctness function (in this experiment, we employ the F1-score). If this score exceeds a predefined threshold Fsubscript{F_{\tau}}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the input is considered correct; otherwise, it is deemed incorrect. Simultaneously, we evaluate the output logits using the uncertainty methods U{U}italic_U outlined in Table 7 to obtain an uncertainty score
U(x;y^)^U(x;\hat{y})italic_U ( italic_x ; over^ start_ARG italic_y end_ARG ). Finally, we calculate the AUROC metric based on F(x,y^)subscript^{F_{\tau}}(x,\hat{y})italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x , over^ start_ARG italic_y end_ARG ) and
U(x;y^)^U(x;\hat{y})italic_U ( italic_x ; over^ start_ARG italic_y end_ARG ) to derive the final result.
